title: Not syncing with the network
body:
#### System information

Geth version: 1.12.0-stable-e501b3b0
CL client & version: prysm v4.0.7
OS & Version: Linux / Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS

#### Hardware specifications of the system:
- CPU: 8 cores
- RAM: 16 GB
- Storage: 2 TB HDD

#### Expected behaviour
eth.syncing -> false


#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
##### geth
````
geth   --mainnet   --datadir /root/data-blockchainb-network   --port 30303   --syncmode "snap"   --cache=2048   --http   --http.addr "localhost"   --http.port "8545"   --http.api "eth,net,web3"   --http.corsdomain "*"   --maxpeers 50   --authrpc.addr localhost   --authrpc.port 8551   --authrpc.vhosts localhost   --authrpc.jwtsecret /root/Ethereum/secrets/jwt.hex
````
##### prysm
````
prysm.sh beacon-chain --datadir=/root/Ethereum/prysm/data --execution-endpoint=http://localhost:8551 --jwt-secret=/root/Ethereum/secrets/jwt.hex --suggested-fee-recipient=0x01234567722E6b0000012BFEBf6177F1D2e9758D9 --checkpoint-sync-url=https://beaconstate.ethstaker.cc
````

#### output command eth.syncing

````
{
  currentBlock: 17946584,
  healedBytecodeBytes: 3779603,
  healedBytecodes: 519,
  healedTrienodeBytes: 874756829,
  healedTrienodes: 2217499,
  healingBytecode: 0,
  healingTrienodes: 1108,
  highestBlock: 17946688,
  startingBlock: 17903716,
  syncedAccountBytes: 54018753452,
  syncedAccounts: 276855529,
  syncedBytecodeBytes: 6993652764,
  syncedBytecodes: 1017474,
  syncedStorage: 1057366175,
  syncedStorageBytes: 227347927578
}
````

#### output run geth

It's been over 9 days since I started running the geth node, but it still hasn't synced with the network. Am I on the right path?
I'm always about 100 blocks behind the network.

Same problem here, not 1 but 2 different machines, one is 2vCPU 8GB RAM 1.2TB NVMe , the other 4vCPU 16GB RAM 1.5 TB 1000MB/s 16k IOPS. Different providers, different networks.

Both stuck at healing phase... since days!

I will try to run Nethermind client to see if that also happens.

Both running:
```

What is the result of this check, have you succeeded in synchronizing?

> #### Hardware specifications of the system:
> - CPU: 8 cores
> - RAM: 16 GB
> - Storage: 2 TB HDD

Geth will probably not succeed on an HDD, the latency is too high, particularly during the heal-phase. 


> one is 2vCPU 8GB RAM 1.2TB NVMe

That looks better, IO-wise, but 2 cpu and a mere 8GB RAM is very much on the low end. 

>  the other 4vCPU 16GB RAM 1.5 TB 1000MB/s 16k IOPS.

I don't know what the disk backend is, I mean, 1GB/s sounds like a lot, but it's not only raw transfer-speed that matters, but also the latency. There are a lot of small reads and writes being performed.

If you both have been healing for days, then it's highly likely that you are not getting any closer to being synced, rather the opposite (the state is getting more and more stale as the time goes by, and you are not catching up). I would recommend beefier machines, with NVMe-SSD disks, at least 16 GB ram (preferrably more), and more cores. 

I'm closing this ticket now: these sort of tickets usually become pretty long-winded hardware discussions, and does not actually document and open bug in go-ethereum.

Sorry to re-open but wanted to give an update, maybe it can help others (feel free to close again)


1) My 16GB machine synced after replacing prysm with lighthouse (still using `geth` as executor), it finally synced, and works fine, so geth+lighthouse works for me.
2) The smaller machine of 8GB I replaced geth for nethermind and kept prysm, but struggled to sync, the process kept dying ("Killed" panic, so probably out of memory)
3) I added supervisor on the processes so if they crash they are auto-restarted, this really did the trick for the 16GB machine + lighthouse (it crashed a few times, but not as much as on the 8GB machine.)
4) For the smaller machine I am moving to lighthouse and keeping nethermind, to see how it behaves now.
5) I have now another larger machine 32GB 8vCPU 2TB NVMe and that one is syncing without problems so far using prysm + geth.

So it could all come to hardware power as @holiman mentioned, try different setups.

Hope this helps!
